2025 IA H 406
Author: Wichtendahl
Version: Introduced
Version Date: 02/13/2025

HF 406 - Introduced

HOUSE FILE 406

BY WICHTENDAHL

A BILL FOR

An Act relating to restrictions on the use of artificial intelligence, and creating a civil cause of action.

BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF THE STATE OF IOWA:

Section 1. NEW SECTION. 554I.1 Definitions.

1. “Application” means a software program designed for an electronic device to enable a user to perform a particular task or set of related tasks including checking the weather, playing games, accessing social media, or managing personal information, within the capabilities of the electronic device.

2. “Artificial intelligence” means any machine-based system that, for any explicit or implicit objective, infers from the inputs the system receives to generate outputs, including content, decisions, predictions, or recommendations, that can influence physical or virtual environments.

3. “Developer” means a person who, in this state, creates or substantially modifies artificial intelligence or an application that uses artificial intelligence.

4. a. “Device company” means a person engaged in the business of manufacturing smart devices and that has a registered office, a registered agent, or a business office in this state.

b. “Device company” includes a registrant as defined in section 548.101, that engages in the business of manufacturing smart devices.

5. “Initialize” means the process of starting a smart device and associating the smart device with a new user account.

6. “Private data” means data that artificial intelligence, or an application that includes artificial intelligence, accesses on a smart device, and that is not any of the following:

a. Content that was generated by using the artificial intelligence or the application on the smart device.

b. Content to which the artificial intelligence’s developer or the application’s developer had previously received authorization to access for purposes described in the smart device’s statement of purpose or the application’s statement of purpose.

7. “Smart device” means a computer, smartphone, gaming console, tablet computer, or other electronic device capable of running software to download, install, or use artificial intelligence and that was sold in this state on or after July 1, 2025.

8. “Statement of purpose” means a statement made for an application or smart device that explains all of the following:

a. The types of private data the application or smart device was designed to access.

b. How the private data will be used, including but not limited to the types of new content the private data will be used to generate and how the new content will be used.

c. If the application or smart device is designed to save, copy, or otherwise transfer private data to a location outside the smart device, an explanation of how and where private data will be maintained, disseminated, and deleted, as applicable.

Sec. 2. NEW SECTION. 554I.2 Device company requirements.

1. a. If a device company makes a smart device available for purchase with artificial intelligence installed on the smart device, the device company shall cause an agreement to appear when a user initializes the smart device. The agreement shall contain all of the following:

(1) A notice to the smart device’s user that the smart device has artificial intelligence installed on the smart device.

(2) If the smart device’s artificial intelligence is designed to access the user’s private data, the smart device’s statement of purpose.

(3) (a) An option to uninstall the artificial intelligence.

(b) If the smart device’s user does not uninstall the artificial intelligence under subparagraph division (a), an interactive form that will allow the smart device’s user to refuse the smart device’s artificial intelligence access to each type of private data the artificial intelligence is designed to access on the smart device prior to the artificial intelligence accessing the private data.

b. The requirements of paragraph “a” shall be separate from any other agreement or disclaimer the device company requires or is required to create for the smart device, including but not limited to terms of service agreements and end user license agreements.

2. If a device company changes any information contained in the statement of purpose for a smart device, the device company shall do all of the following:

a. Update the agreement described in subsection 1.

b. Cause the updated agreement described in subsection 1 to appear on each smart device affected by the change and which has not authorized or refused access to private data based on the change.

3. If a device company causes a smart device the device company manufactured to install artificial intelligence, the device company shall not do any of the following:

a. Permit the artificial intelligence installed on the smart device to access a type of private data that the artificial intelligence was not authorized to access in an agreement described in subsection 1.

b. Use private data accessed by the artificial intelligence in a manner that is not stated in the smart device’s statement of purpose.

c. If the artificial intelligence saves, copies, or otherwise transfers private data to a location outside a smart device from which the private data originated, maintain, disseminate, or delete the private data in a manner that is inconsistent with the smart device’s statement of purpose.

4. a. A device company shall not require a smart device user to install artificial intelligence on the smart device as a condition to use the smart device.

b. A device company shall include clearly identifiable means to allow a user to uninstall artificial intelligence from a smart device if the artificial intelligence was installed on the smart device due to an action taken by the device company.

Sec. 3. NEW SECTION. 554I.3 Developer requirements.

1. a. If a developer makes an application that includes artificial intelligence, makes the application available for general use, and designs the application to access private data, the developer shall cause an agreement to appear on the initial start up of the application on the smart device to which the application was installed. The agreement shall contain all of the following:

(1) A notice to the application’s user that the application includes artificial intelligence and the application is designed to access private data.

(2) The application’s statement of purpose.

(3) An interactive form that will provide the application’s user the ability to refuse the application access to each type of private data the application is designed to access prior to the application accessing the private data.

b. The requirements of paragraph “a” shall be separate from any other agreement or disclaimer the application’s developer requires or is required to create for use of the application, including but not limited to terms of service agreements and end user license agreements.

2. If an application’s developer changes any information contained in the application’s statement of purpose, the application’s developer shall do all of the following:

a. Update the agreement described in subsection 1.

b. Cause the updated agreement described in subsection 1 to appear on each smart device affected by the change which has not authorized or refused access to private data based on the change.

3. A developer of an application that includes artificial intelligence shall not do any of the following:

a. Permit the application to access a type of private data on a smart device that the application was not authorized to access in an agreement described in subsection 1.

b. Use private data accessed by the application in a manner that is not stated in the application’s statement of purpose.

c. If the application saves, copies, or otherwise transfers private data to a location outside a smart device from which the private data originated, maintain, disseminate, or delete the private data in a manner that is inconsistent with the application’s statement of purpose.

Sec. 4. NEW SECTION. 554I.4 Rights to likeness.

On or after July 1, 2025, a person shall not use artificial intelligence to intentionally recreate the audio or visual likeness of an individual without the consent of the individual if the likeness was intended to be substantially indistinguishable from the individual and the likeness is used in any of the following ways:

1. Commercial activity.

2. A political campaign which the individual does not support.

3. A manner intended to make other persons believe that the individual engages in activities the individual would reasonably find offensive.

4. A manner intended to diminish the individual’s credibility, cause embarrassment, or otherwise lower the individual’s esteem within the individual’s community.

5. A manner intended to induce a person to take an action or divulge information the person otherwise would not.

Sec. 5. NEW SECTION. 554I.5 Civil liability — damages — additional remedies.

1. A person may bring an action for actual and punitive damages for a violation of this chapter, including reasonable attorney fees and costs. Punitive damages shall not exceed two hundred fifty thousand dollars for each violation.

2. A class action may be brought under this chapter in accordance with the Iowa rules of civil procedure.

3. The court shall specify the amount of each of the following for each violation of this chapter:

a. Actual damages.

b. Punitive damages.

c. Court costs.

d. Reasonable attorney fees.

4. In determining the punitive damages for a violation of this chapter, the court shall consider all of the following:

a. The nature and extent of the violation.

b. The severity of the violation.

c. The potential economic effect of the punitive damages on the person who violated this chapter.

d. The good-faith measures the person who violated this chapter took to comply with this chapter.

e. The willfulness of the violation.

f. The deterrent effect that the imposition of punitive damages will have.

g. Any other factors the court finds appropriate.

5. a. For purposes of imposing punitive damages under this chapter, a device company is considered to have committed a separate violation of section 554I.2 for each smart device manufactured on or after July 1, 2025, that is initialized in this state.

b. For purposes of imposing punitive damages under this chapter, a developer shall be considered to have committed a separate violation of section 554I.3 for each smart device that uses the developer’s artificial intelligence or application on or after July 1, 2025, in this state.

c. For purposes of imposing punitive damages under this chapter, a person shall be considered to have committed a separate violation of section 554I.4 for each day a violation continues.

6. This chapter shall not preclude a person from bringing a civil or criminal action under any other provision of law.
